newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Asia stocks mixed, Hang Seng hit by Deng rumours.
newsitem.headline: Asia stocks mixed, Hang Seng hit by Deng rumours.

text.p: Asia stock markets closed mixed on Wednesday, with Hong Kong registering the biggest reversal, as caution replaced early euphoria brought on by a powerful advance on Wall Street overnight.
The Hang Seng Index plunged 222.66 points, or 1.65 percent, to 13,239.95 after rumours resurfaced about the health of China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping.
"It is all about Deng's health. I do not know how solid the rumours are, but after lunch the buyers disappeared," one index futures trader said.
Index futures fell in tandem with the cash market, with the February Hang Seng Index contract dropping to a low of 13,000, a drop of 420 points, on volume of more than 16,000 contracts.
"The fall was quite surprising and has caught everybody a bit wrong-footed," one broker said.
By contrast, stocks in Tokyo ended higher, although off the day's highs, inspired by a weak yen.
The key Nikkei 225 share Index ended up 278.10 points, or 1.51 percent, at 18,688.06. At one stage it reached 18,854.76.
"The weak yen is the only remedy left for the Japanese economy when the government tightens its fiscal policies," said Hiroyuki Nakai, chief investment strategist at Nikko Securities.
The yen's weakness reflected a recent and almost unrestrained advance in the U.S. dollar.
Some of that momentum was lost on Thursday after a senior official of the Bundesbank, Germany's powerful central bank, reiterated concern about about the dollar's rise.

"I once more underline, it is not in the interest of the Bundesbank that the strength of the dollar goes further and further," Bundesbank vice-president Johann Wilhelm Gaddum said while attending a regional central bankers meeting in Bangkok.
Analysts said Gaddum's remarks reminded the market that the Group of Seven (G-7) major industrial nations could launch an attack in the foreign exchange market to stem the dollar's rise.
The dollar ended at 124.10/20 yen compared with 124.20/30 in New York on Wednesday, and at 1.6808/15 marks against 1.6890/95.

Wall Street's spectacular 103.52 point advance to 6,961.63 was sparked by a rally in the technology sector following strong earnings from semiconductor equipment maker Applied Materials. The upbeat mood quickly spilled over to other sectors.
A strengthening of the dollar against the mark and yen also aided the market, because it encouraged a flow of funds into U.S. shares, analysts said.

Korean stocks ended higher but off its highs on a bout of profit-taking. News that a high-ranking North Korean official, Hwang Jang-yop, had defected to the South had little impact on the market. It ended 4.21 points, or 0.59 percent, higher at 716.71.
Expectations of a recovery in the semiconductor market bolstered chip makers, traders said. Samsung Electronics, the world's leading chip maker, rose 2,700 won at 59,000.
Taiwan shares soared to a six-year high by the close, aided by Wall Street's gains. The weighted index closed 112.18 points, or 1.51 percent higher, at 7,536.28.
That surpassed Wednesday's 7,424.10 close, and was the highest since the market wound up at 7,857.01 on June 2, 1990.
Thai shares were battered by heavy foreign selling amid concerns over the baht's slide against the U.S. dollar. The SET Index fell 28.42 points, or 3.93 points, at 694.15.
Philippine shares forfeited early gains on the back of Wall Street's rise, and ended lower. The main index closed 4.10 points, or 0.12 percent, down at 3,335.73 points.
Jakarta shares hit a new high of 706.285, after touching a record high on Wednesday. The Jakarta Composite Index was up 5.23 points, or 0.75 percent, at 703.42.
Singapore stocks rallied, with the Straits Times Index up 25.68 points, or 1.15 percent, at 2,250.32, while Malaysian shares were up 6.12 points, or 0.49 percent, at 1,260.54.
